statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Fairfield 67, Loyola, Md. 59
article.story: BALTIMORE (AP) -- Mike Van Schaick scored 26 points, and Fairfield knocked Loyola of Maryland out of first place in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference with a 67-59 victory on Sunday. Anthony Johnson added 15 points, and Greg Nero had 12 for the Stags (11-16, 9-6 MAAC), who have won eight of nine. Omari Isreal scored 13 points for the Greyhounds (14-11, 10-5), who fell one game behind first-place Marist. Gerald Brown, the Greyhounds' leading scorer with a 22-point average, was held to 12 points, and Brett Harvey scored 11. Fairfield shot 52.6 percent from the field, including 5-for-7 from 3-point range, in the second half. Van Schaick went 7-for-13 from the field, including 4-for-7 beyond the arc, and made all eight of his free-throw attempts. The Stags led 24-20 at halftime and built a 53-36 lead in the second half before Loyola rallied. With less than five minutes remaining, the Greyhounds made six straight free throws to get within 58-48. Missed free throws by the Stags opened the door for a 9-2 Loyola run that made it 63-59 with less than a minute remaining. But Van Schaick's two free throws and Johnson's dunk ended Loyola's comeback hopes. The Greyhounds shot 30.8 percent (16 of 52) from the field.
